cases.patient_summary: 14-year-old male with 12-year diagnostic odyssey, misdiagnosed with ASD, progressive neurodegeneration. Re-run with 77,000-word expanded medical records from 8 providers across 12 years
cases.correct_diagnosis: Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis (NCL/Batten disease), CLN5 or CLN6 variant
cases.system_diagnosis: CLN2 Disease (Late-Infantile Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis / Batten Disease), enzymatically confirmed by TPP1 activity 0.8 nmol/hr/mg (<5% of normal). Identified that the diagnosis had already been made by Dr. Osei in 2021 but was LOST in military records transfer.
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. With expanded 77,000-word medical records spanning 8 providers across 12 years, the system identified CLN2/Batten disease at 0.91 confidence. Correctly identified the pathognomonic TPP1 enzyme result, bilateral macular changes, photoparoxysmal EEG response, and progressive cerebellar atrophy. Critically, recognized that Dr. Osei had ALREADY made the correct diagnosis in 2021 but it was lost during military records transfer. All three specialists unanimously agreed ASD was diagnostic overshadowing. The physical therapist's landmark letter was identified as the most effective diagnostic contribution.
key_amendments: Rehabilitation Medicine Consultant added to team topology
cases.high_context_note: Re-run with 77,084 words of expanded medical records (full provider binder). Confidence increased from 0.55 to 0.91 with complete context.

cases.patient_summary: 17-year-old female varsity soccer player with 6-month progressive decline, multiple specialist visits
cases.correct_diagnosis: Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenoma) with concurrent Graves disease, possible MEN2A syndrome
cases.system_diagnosis: Graves disease (autoimmune thyrotoxicosis) with concurrent primary hyperparathyroidism, suspected MEN2A
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. Identified both the thyrotoxicosis AND the parathyroid adenoma, and correctly flagged MEN2A as the unifying genetic syndrome. Connected the family history of thyroid surgery.
cases.original_misdiagnosis: Anxiety, eating disorder, IBS, vasovagal syncope, MVP

cases.patient_summary: 34-year-old female elementary school teacher with 18-month progressive multisystem disease, fragmented across 6 providers
cases.correct_diagnosis: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with lupus nephritis (Class III or IV)
cases.system_diagnosis: SLE with active proliferative lupus nephritis, pending confirmatory serology (anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm, anti-U1 RNP)
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. Correctly identified SLE with lupus nephritis as the primary diagnosis. Appropriately flagged MEN2A overlap possibility. Observer caught premature closure in R1 (all specialists at 0.88-0.92 confidence without confirmatory serology) and forced differential expansion to include cryoglobulinemia and viral-associated syndromes. Final confidence of 0.68 reflects calibrated uncertainty pending specific antibody results.
key_amendments: Classification Criteria vs. Diagnostic Evidence Firewall
cases.original_misdiagnosis: Burnout, repetitive strain, recurrent viral infections, sunburn, stress alopecia, viral pleurisy

cases.patient_summary: 52-year-old male farmer with 2-year progressive cognitive decline, tremor, and personality changes, misdiagnosed as early-onset Alzheimer's
cases.correct_diagnosis: Chronic heavy metal poisoning (lead and/or mercury) from occupational and environmental exposure
cases.system_diagnosis: Chronic lead poisoning (plumbism) with lead encephalopathy, motor-predominant lead neuropathy, lead colic, sideroblastic/hemolytic anemia, and lead nephropathy with saturnine gout
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. Correctly identified chronic lead poisoning as the primary diagnosis, recognizing the Burton line as pathognomonic, the bilateral wrist drop as classic lead neuropathy, and the full lead poisoning pentad (encephalopathy, neuropathy, colic, anemia, nephropathy). Correctly dismissed the prior Alzheimer's diagnosis based on atypical progression rate and motor findings. Identified all three environmental exposure sources.
cases.original_misdiagnosis: Early-onset Alzheimer's disease, depression, essential tremor, IBS-C, diabetic neuropathy, periodontal disease

cases.patient_summary: 4-month-old female infant with poor feeding, failure to thrive, tachypnea, and perioral cyanosis, undiagnosed large VSD with heart failure
cases.correct_diagnosis: Large perimembranous ventricular septal defect (VSD) with congestive heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and failure to thrive
cases.system_diagnosis: Large perimembranous VSD (8mm) with hemodynamically significant L-to-R shunt causing CHF, cardiac-mediated failure to thrive, and developing pulmonary hypertension
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. Confirmed the echo-identified VSD as the cause of CHF and FTT. Identified head-sparing growth pattern as discriminating for caloric deprivation. Flagged 22q11.2 deletion risk requiring chromosomal microarray before surgical planning. Noted the missing ECG as a critical gap for NKX2-5 screening. Recognized the lactation consultant as the one provider who correctly identified the cardiac origin.
cases.original_misdiagnosis: Poor latch, normal variant tachypnea, normal variant cardiomegaly, viral URI, examiner variation hepatomegaly

cases.patient_summary: 28-year-old African American female graphic designer with 3-year history of episodic severe pain crises, chronic joint pain, recurrent leg ulcers, and unprovoked PE, hemolysis markers in chart for over a year but never connected
cases.correct_diagnosis: Sickle cell disease (likely HbSC or sickle-beta thalassemia variant) with vaso-occlusive crises, chronic hemolytic anemia, leg ulcers, and sickle cell-related pulmonary embolism
cases.system_diagnosis: Sickle cell disease (compound heterozygous, most likely HbSC or HbS/beta+-thalassemia) with vaso-occlusive crises, Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia, medial malleolar leg ulcers, and sickle cell-associated PE
cases.diagnostic_accuracy: Highly accurate. Correctly identified sickle cell disease and distinguished the likely compound heterozygous genotype (HbSC or HbS/beta+-thalassemia) based on delayed clinical onset at age 25, normocytic MCV, and moderate anemia. Connected all manifestations: vaso-occlusive crises, hemolytic anemia, medial malleolar ulcers, and PE. Identified the brother's history as strongly suggestive. Flagged hemolysis markers that sat unaddressed in the chart for over a year.
cases.original_misdiagnosis: Musculoskeletal pain, costochondritis, anxiety, fibromyalgia, nonspecific ulceration, unprovoked PE
